The good news is that by anticipating these potential costs, we can prepare for and reduce them. Policymakers, health care providers, and institutions of civil society should think creatively about how to mitigate the looming challenge—starting now.

The decline in social capital among the elderly, by increasing demand for institutional care, is likely to worsen federal and state deficits. Current projections of spending on Medicare and Medicaid inadequately account for declining social support.

While care provided informally creates costs such as the lost wages of caregivers, institutional care often entails burdensome expenses. Paying the cost of long-term care privately is prohibitively expensive for many families.

Future retirees will require a greater amount of institutional care outside the home and away from loved ones, reducing, for many, their quality of life. There are also financial implications for the elderly and their families.

It’s time for Democrats like Sen. Durbin to keep politics out of the post office. We need to give our letter carriers, local post masters, and other USPS employees the resources they need to do their jobs. They shouldn’t be pawns in the Democrats’ partisan games.

And I’d just like to note - I have been in Congress since 2013. @SenatorDurbin has been in Congress since 1983. What accomplishments from his 37 years in office can he point to that have addressed the long-term solvency problems of the @USPS?
Finally – I have long been an opponent of USPS privatization. I strongly believe that USPS should remain an entity of the US Government, which the Constitution empowers Congress to do.

I’ve also supported legislation to maintain 6-day delivery, door delivery for residences and businesses, and maintain 2012 service standards, not just in the 116th Congress, but in past Congresses as well. Learn more about those bills here: https://rodneydavis.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=403854

I’ve co-sponsored H.R. 2382, the USPS Fairness Act, which passed the House on a bipartisan basis this past February. The bill would provide needed cash flow by repealing the mandate that USPS has to pre-fund future retirement benefits.

Over 3 months ago, I sent a letter to leaders of my own party urging them to include federal assistance to USPS, including the $25 billion appropriation that’s now being discussed, in additional COVID-19 relief legislation. You can find that letter here: https://rodneydavis.house.gov/uploadedfiles/usps_gop_covid19_relief_letter_5.5.2020.pdf
